comments.commentBody: President Boren was the governor of Oklahoma and, more recently, a powerful senator before taking this position.  He still sits on the President's Intelligence Board.  Politically, he was the guy who mended political fences to get things done.  When I was at OU he actually taught political science.  He's a hard-working and decent guy.

David L. Boren sounds like a good guy.
Old school. We need more people like him in public life.

Depression is a very democratic aggressor.

A 40 something woman who is very dear to me suffers from mild depression all her life. This despite the fact that she has absolutely nothing to be depressed of. Loving, faithful and adoring husband? Checked. Money? More than enough to maintain several residences around the globe. Beauty? Way beyond average. Physical health? Excellent. Children? All brilliant, all well-behave. Intelligence? A graduate from top university. Friendships? Checked. Social skill? Her annual Christmas party is attended by ambassadors and the local Nuncio.
And yet she is always mildly depressed. She never complain. But we know she is depressed.
We can never understand her.
Yet animals are always very much drawn to her. Dogs, cats, horses, anything with four legs. This despite the fact that she doesn't really like animals! Observing how animals behave around her, I learn how to make her feel better. Be patient, be there, and be ready to help without being disruptive. And most importantly, be understanding without being patronizing.

I was simply sharing a common experience with multiple commenters. I did not mean for my anecdotal story to be perceived as an empirical study with quantitative data. In no way was I trying to be a case study. I was just sharing a story about my experience that related to those commenters who
mentioned the challenges of letting a baby cry themselves to sleep, which is what my father did. While I was sleeping during the day, I don't know if I was sleeping for long periods of time.

I mentioned recall development of the brain not brain development. The brain develops from neural creation after conception until the 20s and is constantly changing and adapting. The ability for the brain to recall information from the past occurs at about six months, according to multiple sources including college level neurology textbooks. The point I was trying to make was that I did not remember what I experienced at two months later in my life.
Similar experience with Merrill Lynch (before they went under); moved to Fidelity.  At least now, no  one to blame but me. Index funds aren't all bad.

When those brokers are pushing a stock, it's almost a certainty that they want to sell their stake.  Try reading books like "The Fast Forward MBA," by John Waggoner.  It's old, but you will learn a lot.
Well said.  Also read the classic from 1940:  "Where are the Customer's yachts?"

The biggest problem is, most people are not investors, they want someone else to take their money and make some gins with it for them.

Even a fiduciary is not perfect, but is certainly better than many brokers. I had a Morgan Stanley account, and the broke gave me some good advice, I still have some of the equities she suggested several years ago. But she also had me buy one stock, that turned out to be a dog. MS had a big investment in it, they were one of the underwriters.. I was wary of it, but she made it sound pretty reliable. I think MS put her in the position of selling it for their benefit.

That was when I moved my accounts to Schwab. But she was not a fiduciary, if she had been, she might have been more careful. It cost her my account, and all the commissions that went with it.

I have a very good broker with Schwab, I use him for advice, but do my own buying and selling, so I am my own fiduciary. I do not care how good your financial adviser is, You should not invest without understanding what it is you are investing in, and having knowledge of investing.

Notice the recent finding on funds, the great majority of them have done no better, in fact even worse than the S&P. Funds are a racket, you pay someone to put your money somewhere, they get paid even if you lose.

Read Benjamin Graham's "The Intelligent Investor," the person that taught Buffett how to invest.

In most countries - including European countries -  if a patient has a seizure, the neurologist or neurosurgeon is required to notify the DMV to suspend the drivers license. This is a widely accepted situation where public safety requirements are accepted to trump personal privacy. If a physician believes that a person - because of their occupation - poses a substantial safety risk, then a specific reporting channel should be required. We do this for elder abuse and child abuse as well. A confidential board - such as a pilot's organization - could then review the information with it's own medical staff and issue a hold on a flight readiness certification when the level of concern is high enough.

This young man would never have implemented his actions had there been another person in the cockpit. He was waiting to be alone. He was not violent. A conversation with another person would have taken him on another train of thought. Mr. Winkelmann of Germanwings is so wrong: it's absolutely necessary to always have two crew members in the cockpit, we are dealing with human beings, and they are not perfect and need to be checked. I am glad that most all countries have now implemented the 2 crew cockpit rule, just as the US has had it since 9/11.
My thoughts are with all the families of the casualties, this is just too sad.
Yes, he was, in 2009 while he was training.

As I understand from this article, the discretion to disclose whether he has a condition that should prevent him from piloting is vested in the co-pilot and only the co-pilot. His doctor has limited discretion to report his patient's condition to the authorities. What's the incentive for the pilot to admit to having a condition that's stigmatized by the public, that might affect his career, and recuse himself from his livelihood, other than a sense of honor and duty?

I do want to respect one's medical privacy, but when there is no checks and balances system on someone whose medical records would be highly pertinent to his job and would affect the public -- a police officer, a surgeon, etc. -- arguably, a revision of the current law is in order.

You can't find them because they're not there.
Yes, he had an episode of depression in 2009 while he was training. But the French prosecutor and the media have grabbed that incident and have run with it. It makes for a good scapegoat in any case.
As for a medical doctor giving him a sick note excusing him from working 1 day meaning that he was suffering from a mental health issue, all I can ask is, would he have been better the next day?
Also, a flight attendant might be easily overpowered.

There should be 3 pilots on a plane at all times, with one serving as the 2nd person in the cockpit when one of the other pilots leaves it for any reason.  Only another pilot could take over the controls and keep it flying - not a flight attendant.
Well sounds like he'll be 60 soon, retire, and no longer be a danger to the rest of us.

My sister's ex-husband is a pilot and has been all his adult life. They lived 1200 miles away from me but I became aware they would return once a year to a Memphis location for his physical. I inquired as to why he didn't go to a local doctor. She told me that he had high blood pressure and couldn't pass a physical by a doctor that would not fudge the numbers. I became aware that he was also an alcoholic which surely didn't help his BP. My sister would drive him in the evenings because getting a DUI would "cause problems with his pilots license." He's in his late 50's now, still flys all over the world. I often wondered how many other pilots were cheating on their physicals.

We need New Rules for pilot physicals; there should also be a psychological profile as well. It should not be a company dr that will conveniently change the numbers or a favored dr in another town.

You state: "This is a random tragic event" Let us look at some other possible tragic events that could be considered a random tragic event. How about a nuclear power plant operator licensed by NRC (Nuclear Regulatory Commission). What if his condition was not revealed to his employer and in the case of an event at a nuclear facility thousands of square miles in our country including cities with thousands of people be made uninhabitable for thousands of years. All this nightmare scenario because we need to protect an individuals privacy. Give  me a break.

Imagine if we could sideline someone from work or another activity based solely on a doctor's note to, say, an employer.
Do some occupations warrant this kind of oversight?
I hope not.
This is a random tragic event.
Preventable?
Not yesterday, but maybe with better engineering on cabin doors or better procedures to not leave pilots alone in the cockpit, we can avoid this from happening again.
But only til the next random tragic event.

Obviously depression cannot be the sole cause of a likely mass murder.  If Mr Lubitz was a psychopath there are no tests good enough to detect that through screening.  for me the best test is well paid  senior pilot with grey hair - you can keep the under-paid 20 somethings.
Please give a reference.

Innocent people do in fact do this. They even confess to murder. They even go so far as to confess the murder of their children when it turns out they are completely innocent. ( read about the Kevin Fox case for example)

None of us wants to accept that we are so frail that we would make a false confession or a false accusation. It seems impossible. It is not. We know it happens. We also know it is most often really not the fault of the person who has made the statement. It is the result of improper interrogation techniques that are not designed to find the truth but rather confirm what the police have decided is true. Ms Knoxs statement was made under just such circumstances.

What about on the oil rigs? Or automotive mechanics? Or garbagemen..err... persons of garbage disposal. Where's the outcries there? Or is it just a pick-and-choose, these are nice cushy jobs that pay well, so we demand equality there.

With nothing preventing women from starting their own firms one has to ask why there isn't a fem-tech sector mushrooming up.

Instead we have this law suit because this woman feels she can't operate in the old boys club and she wants that world changed to suit her.

With that victim perspective no wonder women aren't starting their own firms.
Is venture capital even really tech? How many of these VC people are really just finance people or lawyers, cultures legendary  for their inclusiveness ?
or perhaps, when thoughtfully designed structures and policies help correct for bias, and level the playing field.  It's not always the case, but is possible.
Absolutely. Just Google "reply all" and "Tucker Carlson" for a great example.

I think that's it. The biases were too subtle. I've seen SO much worse in tech that when I read her case, I felt really dismayed because I knew she was doomed and, to some extent, taking us down with her.
Thank you. I've read so many venomous male responses to this case today that this was very much needed. The things I've seen and heard in tech would make anyone's head spin.

How about some data:
http://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2014/09/30/male-entrepreneurs-get-si...

I would like to see a fem-tech industry mushroom up. I think it would be interesting to see what kind of devices and technology an 'old girls club' would come up with.

We've got enough Apple and Microsoft and Google and facebook boys in their garages and dorm rooms.

The thing is I don't think women lean toward that kind of creativity. The industry is so completely male for a reason. Men are just built for designing and building the kind of tech stuff we (men and women both) enjoy using. If this weren't true, things wouldn't be as they are in the valley.

At the end of the article, Peter Fenton refers to hiring a woman as "diversity" and a "risk." That, alone, has to shine a pretty stark light on what that environment is like. Time magazine published a piece yesterday about all-male leadership teams being 4x more likely than those that include even one woman to receive VC funding. Yet, despite all this information, she'd slept with a partner which was rookie and unprofessional, her case was never strong, it was high-profile, and she lost. All I read today is venom from men saying that the "bitch got what she deserved." I don't think it did anything good for women. I think it did for gender discrimination what Rolling Stone did for women on college campuses.
